Package model

Class Entity

java.lang.Object
model.Entity
Direct Known Subclasses:
Bullet, Coin, Explosion, House, Invader, InvaderCluster, InvaderGoal, Player, Rect, Turret
public abstract class Entity extends Object
Entity is a universal game object that participates in an entity system. It follows a hierarchical structure with parent and children nodes, providing a flexible way to organize game objects. This system allows for quickly and easily attaching code and elements into the game. The system will also handle deleting components for further ease of access. Example usage: Invader invader = new Invader(game); Entity.instantiate(game, invader); Example continued: invader.addChild(new Sprite(game));

  • Constructor Details

    • Entity

      public Entity(Game game, float x, float y)
      Spawn entity at a given position.
      Parameters:
      game - to instantiate children nodes to.
      x - absolute x position
      y - absolute x position

  • Method Details

    • instantiate

      public static boolean instantiate(Game game, Entity entity)
      Instantiate the given entity into the game loop. This means that the added entity will automatically be called by game when needed. Currently, this means that the .update() method is called every game loop and all keystroke events are handled. In the future this could be expanded to also handle .collision() events. Instantiated entities will automatically be read by other classes and methods when data is needed (colliders for collision, sprites for drawing, and other data such as entity type).
      Parameters:
      game - game to instantiate to
      entity - to instantiate
      Returns:
      whether or not the instantiation was successful.

    • instantiate

      public static void instantiate(Game game, Entity... entities)
      Instantiate the given entities into the game loop. This means that the added entity will automatically be called by game when needed. Currently, this means that the .update() method is called every game loop and all keystroke events are handled. In the future this could be expanded to also handle .collision() events. Instantiated entities will automatically be read by other classes and methods when data is needed (colliders for collision, sprites for drawing, and other data such as entity type).
      Parameters:
      game - game to instantiate to
      entities - ... to instantiate

    • setX

      public void setX(float x)
      Set the position of the entity to a given x position. The x values will be treated as absolute so it will use the topmost parent/game coordinates.
      Parameters:
      x - absolute x position

    • setY

      public void setY(float y)
      Set the position of the entity to a given y position. The y values will be treated as absolute so it will use the topmost parent/game coordinates.
      Parameters:
      y - absolute y position

    • getX

      public float getX()
      Get the position of the entity at a given x position. The x values will be treated as absolute so it will use the topmost parent/game coordinates.
      Returns:
      absolute x position

    • getY

      public float getY()
      Get the position of the entity at a given y position. The y values will be treated as absolute so it will use the topmost parent/game coordinates.
      Returns:
      absolute y position

    • setDx

      public void setDx(float newHorizontalSpeed)
      Set the dx value. This value can later be utilized by any entity to know what direction it should move.
      Parameters:
      newHorizontalSpeed - The new horizontal speed to set it to

    • setDy

      public void setDy(float newVerticalSpeed)
      Set the dy value. This value can later be utilized by any entity to know what direction it should move.
      Parameters:
      newVerticalSpeed - The new vertical speed to set it to

    • getTeam

      public Team getTeam()
      Get the Team this entity is assigned to.
      Returns:
      the Team enum.

    • move

      public void move(float dx, float dy)
      Move the topmost parent entity by the given delta x and delta y offsets.
      Parameters:
      dx - amount to move by
      dy - amount to move by

    • getParent

      public Entity getParent()
      Get the parent of this entity (but not the topmost parent).
      Returns:
      this entitie's parent

    • getChildren

      public List<Entity> getChildren()
      Get the entitie's children list. This is the actual list the entity has.
      Returns:
      a reference to the entitie's list of children

    • update

      public void update()
      Should be overriden to add functionality for game tick updates. If instantiated, the game will be able to call this method on every game update. Will not be called as soon as it is deleted with .delete().

    • onKeyDown

      public void onKeyDown(javafx.event.EventHandler<javafx.scene.input.KeyEvent> event)
      Helper method to add keyevent to entities. The event handlers will be automatically added/frozen/deleted when needed. The only thing the programmer needs to do is specifiy the Event code that should be run. Take great care when modifying any loop inside of an event handler. The code could be running inside a for-loop and changing the size of an associated for-loop could cause a ConcurrentModification exception.
      Parameters:
      event - to be called when a key is pressed down.

    • onKeyUp

      public void onKeyUp(javafx.event.EventHandler<javafx.scene.input.KeyEvent> event)
      Helper method to add keyevent to entities.
      Parameters:
      event - to be called when a key is released.

    • isFrozen

      public boolean isFrozen()
      Check if the current entity is frozen. Frozen entities temporarily stop participating in the events and update() calls.
      Returns:
      whether it is currently frozen

    • setFrozen

      public void setFrozen(boolean isFrozen)
      Set the frozen status of this entity. Frozen entities temporarily stop participating in the events and update() calls.
      Parameters:
      isFrozen - new frozen value to set the entity to.

    • instantiate

      public boolean instantiate()
      Instantiate the given entity into the game loop. This means that the added entity will automatically be called by game when needed. Currently, this means that the .update() method is called every game loop and all keystroke events are handled. In the future this could be expanded to also handle .collision() events. Instantiated entities will automatically be read by other classes and methods when data is needed (colliders for collision, sprites for drawing, and other data such as entity type).
      Returns:
      whether or not the instantiation was successful.

    • delete

      public void delete()
      Delete this entity from the game loop. Deleting an entity from the game loop simply means detaching it from the game objects. The children will also subsequently be removed from the game. All parent/child references will be removed. This is because .delete() usually means you no longer want to use the entity ever again (this is java so all references to this entity or children are valid pointers). If the entity has to remain inside of the game consider using .setFrozen(). If only the parent has to be deleted then use removeChild(Entity child) or removeChild(Entity... child).
